expanded_description: The Phillips Curve trade-off between inflation and unemployment is one of the most consequential concepts in macroeconomics. It suggests that policymakers face a choice: lower unemployment comes at the cost of higher inflation, and lower inflation comes at the cost of higher unemployment. But this trade-off is not simple or stable. It exists only in the short run, depends on expectations, and can be shifted by supply shocks. Understanding the nature of this trade-off—when it exists, when it doesn't, and how it changes—is essential for evaluating policy options and for understanding the constraints policymakers face. In this section, we'll explore the policy implications of the inflation-unemployment trade-off: how policymakers use it, the limits of exploiting it, the costs of reducing inflation, and the role of credibility in shaping the trade-off.

core_concept.principle: The inflation-unemployment trade-off, as depicted by the Phillips Curve, has profound implications for macroeconomic policy. It suggests that policymakers face a short-run trade-off: they can achieve lower unemployment by accepting higher inflation, or lower inflation by accepting higher unemployment. This trade-off arises because changes in aggregate demand move the economy along the short-run Phillips Curve. However, the trade-off is not a menu of permanent options. In the long run, the Phillips Curve is vertical—there is no trade-off. Attempts to permanently lower unemployment below the natural rate lead only to higher inflation, not permanently lower unemployment. The policy implications are several. (1) Demand management matters in the short run: Monetary and fiscal policy can be used to stabilize the economy, reducing unemployment during recessions (accepting temporarily higher inflation) or reducing inflation during booms (accepting temporarily higher unemployment). This is the rationale for countercyclical policy. (2) The natural rate is a constraint: Policymakers cannot sustainably push unemployment below the natural rate without causing accelerating inflation. This is why central banks estimate the natural rate (NAIRU) and use it as a guide. (3) The cost of reducing inflation (the sacrifice ratio) depends on how quickly expectations adjust. If expectations are slow to adjust (adaptive expectations), reducing inflation requires a prolonged period of high unemployment—a costly disinflation. If expectations adjust quickly (rational expectations with credibility), disinflation can be less costly. (4) Credibility matters: A credible central bank can influence expectations, improving the trade-off. If the public believes the central bank will maintain low inflation, expectations remain anchored, allowing lower unemployment without rising inflation. If credibility is lost, the trade-off worsens. (5) Supply shocks complicate the trade-off: Negative supply shocks shift the Phillips Curve upward, worsening the trade-off—both inflation and unemployment rise. Policymakers then face a dilemma: fighting inflation worsens unemployment; fighting unemployment worsens inflation. (6) The trade-off can shift over time: Changes in expectations and supply shocks alter the position of the SRPC, changing the terms of the trade-off. Policymakers must adapt to these shifts. Understanding these implications is essential for evaluating policy choices and for understanding debates about monetary and fiscal policy.
core_concept.explanation: Think of the trade-off like a budget constraint. You have a certain amount of 'pain' (unemployment) and 'gain' (lower inflation) you can trade off. In the short run, you can choose different combinations along the curve. But the curve can shift—sometimes you get a worse deal (more pain for the same gain), sometimes a better deal. And in the long run, there's no trade-off at all—you can't permanently trade pain for gain. Policymakers have to navigate this shifting, temporary trade-off, knowing that their credibility affects where the curve is and how easily they can move along it.

sections.introduction: The Phillips Curve trade-off between inflation and unemployment is at the heart of macroeconomic policy debates. Should policymakers accept higher inflation to reduce unemployment? How much unemployment is worth paying to reduce inflation? What determines the terms of this trade-off? In this section, we'll explore the policy implications of the inflation-unemployment trade-off. We'll examine how policymakers use the trade-off, the limits of exploiting it, the costs of disinflation, the role of credibility, and how supply shocks complicate the picture. Understanding these implications is essential for analyzing real-world policy decisions.

introduction_image.alt: Balance scale with inflation on one side and unemployment on the other
introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.4.2: Policymakers face a trade-off between inflation and unemployment in the short run.

key_concept.definition: The inflation-unemployment trade-off refers to the inverse relationship between inflation and unemployment in the short run, as depicted by the Phillips Curve. This trade-off has several key policy implications. (1) Short-run stabilization: Policymakers can use monetary and fiscal policy to move the economy along the SRPC. During recessions, expansionary policy can reduce unemployment at the cost of higher inflation. During booms, contractionary policy can reduce inflation at the cost of higher unemployment. This is the basis for countercyclical stabilization policy. (2) The natural rate constraint: The trade-off is only temporary. Attempts to keep unemployment below the natural rate lead to accelerating inflation, not permanently lower unemployment. This is why central banks estimate the natural rate (NAIRU) and use it as a guide—if unemployment is below the natural rate, they worry about rising inflation; if above, they see slack. (3) The cost of disinflation: Reducing inflation (disinflation) requires pushing unemployment above the natural rate temporarily. The sacrifice ratio measures the cumulative increase in unemployment (or loss of output) needed to reduce inflation by one percentage point. Estimates vary, but historical experience suggests significant costs—e.g., the Volcker disinflation of the early 1980s caused unemployment to peak at nearly 11%. (4) The role of expectations and credibility: The cost of disinflation depends on how quickly inflation expectations adjust. If expectations are adaptive (based on past inflation), disinflation is costly because expectations adjust slowly. If expectations are rational and the central bank is credible, a disinflation can be less costly because expectations adjust quickly, even before policy takes full effect. This is why central banks emphasize credibility and transparency—to shape expectations and improve the trade-off. (5) Supply shocks worsen the trade-off: Negative supply shocks shift the SRPC upward, causing both higher inflation and higher unemployment. This worsens the trade-off—policymakers face a dilemma where fighting one problem worsens the other. Positive supply shocks improve the trade-off. (6) The trade-off can shift over time: Changes in expectations and supply shocks alter the position of the SRPC, changing the terms of the trade-off. Policymakers must adapt to these shifts. (7) Long-run policy focuses on price stability: Because there is no long-run trade-off, monetary policy cannot permanently reduce unemployment. Its long-run role is to maintain price stability, which provides a favorable environment for growth and employment.
key_concept.context: Understanding the policy implications of the inflation-unemployment trade-off has been central to macroeconomic thinking since the Phillips Curve was discovered. The 1960s belief in a stable trade-off led to policies that contributed to the Great Inflation of the 1970s. The subsequent recognition of the natural rate and the role of expectations transformed monetary policy. Today, central banks around the world use this framework to guide policy, emphasizing credibility, transparency, and inflation targeting. In AP Macroeconomics, understanding these implications is essential for analyzing policy debates and for evaluating the Fed's actions.

classifications.value: Using the trade-off to smooth the business cycle
classifications.behavior: The short-run trade-off gives policymakers a tool for stabilizing the economy. When the economy is in a recession with high unemployment and low inflation, expansionary policy can move the economy up along the SRPC: unemployment falls, inflation rises. This reduces the output gap and speeds recovery. When the economy is overheating with low unemployment and high inflation, contractionary policy can move the economy down along the SRPC: unemployment rises, inflation falls. This cools the economy and prevents inflation from spiraling. The ability to use this trade-off is the foundation of countercyclical monetary and fiscal policy. However, policymakers must recognize that these effects are temporary and that the position of the SRPC matters. If the SRPC has shifted (due to expectations or supply shocks), the same policy action will have different effects on inflation and unemployment. Moreover, policymakers must judge how much inflation they are willing to accept to reduce unemployment, and vice versa—a normative judgment that depends on societal preferences and the central bank's mandate.

image.alt: Phillips Curve graph showing policy moving economy along SRPC to stabilize
image.caption: Figure 8.4.4: Short-run stabilization uses movements along the SRPC to reduce unemployment (expansionary) or reduce inflation (contractionary).

examples.explanation: The Fed cut rates to zero and used QE to stimulate the economy. This moved the economy along the SRPC, helping reduce unemployment from 10% to under 5% over several years, with inflation remaining low.
The Fed raised rates sharply to fight inflation, moving down along the SRPC. This increased unemployment modestly (from 3.4% to around 4%) while reducing inflation from 9% to around 3%.

classifications.behavior: Reducing inflation (disinflation) is not costless. To lower inflation, policymakers must push unemployment above the natural rate temporarily. The sacrifice ratio measures this cost—typically defined as the cumulative percentage point increase in unemployment (or cumulative loss of output) needed to reduce inflation by one percentage point. Estimates of the sacrifice ratio vary, but historical experience suggests it can be substantial. For example, the Volcker disinflation of 1979-82 reduced inflation from over 13% to around 3% but caused unemployment to peak at nearly 11%—a severe recession. The sacrifice ratio depends critically on how quickly inflation expectations adjust. Under adaptive expectations, expectations are based on past inflation, so they adjust slowly. Disinflation then requires a prolonged period of high unemployment to gradually shift expectations downward. Under rational expectations, if the central bank's commitment to lower inflation is credible, expectations may adjust quickly, even before policy takes full effect. This can reduce the sacrifice ratio dramatically—a 'cold turkey' disinflation with lower costs. This is why central banks emphasize credibility and why many have adopted inflation targeting to anchor expectations.

image.alt: Graph showing unemployment above natural rate during disinflation, with sacrifice ratio calculation
image.caption: Figure 8.4.5: Disinflation requires temporarily higher unemployment. The sacrifice ratio measures this cost.

examples.explanation: Inflation fell from over 13% to about 3% (10 percentage points). Unemployment peaked at nearly 11%, about 5 points above the estimated natural rate. The sacrifice ratio was substantial.
Some countries achieved disinflation with lower costs by establishing credibility and using inflation targets to anchor expectations.

classifications.value: How central bank credibility shapes the trade-off
classifications.behavior: Central bank credibility—the public's belief that the central bank will do what it says—plays a crucial role in the inflation-unemployment trade-off. A credible central bank can influence inflation expectations directly. If the public believes the central bank will maintain low inflation, expectations remain anchored even if actual inflation temporarily deviates. This keeps the SRPC stable and improves the trade-off: lower unemployment can be achieved without triggering rising inflation expectations. When the central bank needs to reduce inflation, credibility allows expectations to adjust quickly, reducing the sacrifice ratio. A credible announcement of tighter policy may lower inflation expectations immediately, shifting the SRPC down and reducing the need for a prolonged recession. Conversely, a central bank that lacks credibility faces a worse trade-off. Expectations are unanchored, the SRPC is higher, and disinflation is more costly. Building credibility takes time and requires consistent policy, transparency, and often institutional arrangements like inflation targeting or central bank independence.

image.alt: Two Phillips Curve graphs comparing high credibility (stable SRPC) and low credibility (shifting SRPC)
image.caption: Figure 8.4.6: Credibility improves the trade-off by anchoring expectations and reducing the cost of disinflation.

examples.explanation: The German Bundesbank and later the European Central Bank built strong credibility for low inflation. This allowed them to maintain low inflation even with relatively low unemployment.

In the 1970s, the Fed lacked credibility; expectations were unanchored, and the trade-off was poor. By the 1990s, after Volcker's success, the Fed had high credibility, and expectations remained anchored even as unemployment fell.

principles.principle: The Trade-off Is Temporary, Not Permanent
principles.statement: Perhaps the most important implication of the Phillips Curve analysis is that the inflation-unemployment trade-off exists only in the short run. In the long run, the Phillips Curve is vertical at the natural rate—there is no permanent trade-off. This means policymakers cannot permanently buy lower unemployment by accepting higher inflation. Attempts to do so lead only to accelerating inflation, not permanently lower unemployment. This insight, from Friedman and Phelps, fundamentally changed macroeconomic policy. It implies that the long-run role of monetary policy is to maintain price stability, not to target unemployment below its natural rate. Central banks may use policy to smooth short-run fluctuations, but they must not lose sight of the long-run neutrality of money. The temporary nature of the trade-off also means that the benefits of expansionary policy (lower unemployment) are temporary, while the costs (higher inflation) can persist if expectations become unanchored.
principles.application: When evaluating policy, remember that any gain in unemployment from expansionary policy is temporary. The long-run effect is only on inflation. This is why central banks focus on inflation targets and why they resist political pressure to overstimulate the economy.
principles.example: In the late 1960s, policymakers believed they could permanently lower unemployment by accepting higher inflation. They were wrong. By the 1970s, unemployment was back to its natural rate, but inflation was much higher—the temporary trade-off had disappeared, leaving only higher inflation.

image.alt: Graph showing short-run movement along SRPC then long-run return to natural rate at higher inflation
image.caption: Figure 8.4.7: The trade-off is temporary. In the long run, unemployment returns to the natural rate regardless of inflation.

principles.principle: The Cost of Reducing Inflation Depends on Expectations and Credibility
principles.statement: Disinflation—reducing inflation from a high level—is not costless. It typically requires a period of high unemployment. But the magnitude of this cost (the sacrifice ratio) is not fixed. It depends crucially on how quickly inflation expectations adjust. Under adaptive expectations, where people base expectations on past inflation, disinflation is costly and prolonged. Under rational expectations, if the central bank's commitment to lower inflation is credible, expectations may adjust quickly, reducing the sacrifice ratio. This is why credibility is so valuable. A credible central bank can achieve disinflation with less pain because its announcements shape expectations directly. This insight has led central banks to emphasize transparency, communication, and institutional commitments like inflation targeting. The Volcker disinflation was costly partly because the Fed lacked credibility after years of high inflation; expectations were deeply embedded and slow to change.
principles.application: When analyzing a disinflation, consider the state of expectations and the central bank's credibility. A credible disinflation may be less costly. A disinflation attempted by a central bank with low credibility will likely require a severe recession.
principles.example: In the early 1980s, the Fed under Volcker faced deeply entrenched expectations. Disinflation required a severe recession—unemployment peaked at nearly 11%. In contrast, some countries in the 1990s achieved disinflation with lower costs by establishing credible inflation targets before inflation became entrenched.

image.alt: Graph showing two disinflation paths: one with slow expectations adjustment (high unemployment) and one with fast adjustment (low unemployment)
image.caption: Figure 8.4.8: The cost of disinflation depends on expectations adjustment. Credibility can reduce the sacrifice ratio.

principles.principle: Supply Shocks Worsen the Trade-off and Create Dilemmas
principles.statement: Supply shocks complicate the inflation-unemployment trade-off dramatically. A negative supply shock shifts the SRPC upward, causing both higher inflation and higher unemployment—stagflation. This worsens the trade-off: the same unemployment rate now comes with higher inflation, and the same inflation rate comes with higher unemployment. Policymakers face a dilemma: standard demand-side policies cannot address both problems. Contractionary policy to fight inflation would raise unemployment further; expansionary policy to fight unemployment would raise inflation further. There is no good option. The only way to improve the situation is to address the supply shock directly (through supply-side policies) or to wait for the shock to reverse. This is why supply shocks are particularly challenging for policymakers and why they often lead to difficult trade-offs and policy debates.
principles.application: When a supply shock hits, recognize that the trade-off has worsened. Standard policy prescriptions may be inadequate. Policymakers may need to prioritize one goal over the other, accept temporarily worse outcomes, or look to supply-side solutions.
principles.example: In the 1970s, the oil shocks created stagflation. Policymakers faced a dilemma: fighting inflation would worsen already high unemployment; fighting unemployment would worsen already high inflation. This led to policy confusion and contributed to the 'Great Inflation.'

image.alt: Phillips Curve graph showing upward shift and dilemma arrows pointing in opposite directions
image.caption: Figure 8.4.9: Negative supply shocks worsen the trade-off and create a policy dilemma—fighting one problem worsens the other.

principles.principle: The Natural Rate Is a Crucial Policy Guidepost
principles.statement: The natural rate of unemployment (NAIRU) serves as a crucial guide for monetary policy. When unemployment is below the estimated natural rate, the economy is likely overheating, and inflation will tend to rise. This signals that contractionary policy may be needed. When unemployment is above the natural rate, there is slack, and inflation will tend to fall—signaling that expansionary policy may be appropriate. Central banks constantly monitor estimates of the natural rate to gauge the stance of the economy. However, the natural rate is not directly observable and must be estimated, introducing uncertainty. Estimates can change over time, and mistakes in estimating the natural rate can lead to policy errors. For example, if policymakers underestimate the natural rate, they may think the economy has slack when it is actually overheating, leading to rising inflation. If they overestimate it, they may tighten policy prematurely, causing unnecessary unemployment. Despite these challenges, the natural rate concept remains essential for policy analysis.
principles.application: When evaluating whether policy is appropriately expansionary or contractionary, compare actual unemployment to estimates of the natural rate. A large gap suggests policy may need to adjust. But recognize that estimates are uncertain and can change.
principles.example: In the late 1990s, many economists thought the natural rate was around 5-6%. As unemployment fell to 4% without rising inflation, they revised their estimates downward. The Fed, recognizing this, did not tighten excessively, allowing the expansion to continue.

image.alt: Graph showing actual unemployment vs estimated natural rate, with policy implications
image.caption: Figure 8.4.10: The natural rate guides policy—below it signals overheating, above it signals slack.

worked_examples.title: Calculating the Sacrifice Ratio

image.alt: Table with inflation and unemployment data
image.caption: Figure 8.4.11: Calculate the sacrifice ratio from historical data.

worked_examples.problem: A country reduces inflation from 10% to 4% over 3 years. During this disinflation, unemployment averages 8% while the natural rate is estimated at 5%. a) What is the total percentage point reduction in inflation? b) What is the cumulative unemployment gap (unemployment above natural rate) over the 3 years? c) What is the sacrifice ratio (cumulative unemployment gap per point of inflation reduction)? d) If output loss is estimated at 2% of GDP for each 1% of unemployment above natural rate (Okun's law), what is the cumulative output loss? e) How might credibility affect this calculation?

step_by_step.explanation: Inflation fell from 10% to 4%, a reduction of 6 percentage points.
Each year, unemployment gap = actual - natural = 8% - 5% = 3%. Over 3 years, cumulative gap = 3% × 3 = 9 percentage point-years.

Sacrifice ratio = cumulative unemployment gap / inflation reduction = 9 / 6 = 1.5. This means each 1 percentage point reduction in inflation required 1.5 percentage point-years of excess unemployment.
Okun's law: 1% unemployment above natural for 1 year reduces output by 2%. So cumulative output loss = 9 × 2 = 18% of one year's GDP (spread over 3 years).

If the central bank had high credibility, expectations might have adjusted faster, reducing the needed unemployment gap and sacrifice ratio. The actual ratio reflects the lack of credibility and slow expectations adjustment.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) 6 points. b) 9 point-years. c) 1.5. d) 18% of one year's GDP. e) Credibility would reduce sacrifice ratio.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The sacrifice ratio measures the cost of disinflation. It depends on expectations and credibility.

worked_examples.title: Policy Choice Along the SRPC

image.alt: Phillips Curve graph with points A, B, C showing different inflation-unemployment combinations
image.caption: Figure 8.4.12: Choose among policy options along the SRPC.

worked_examples.problem: The economy is initially at point A on the SRPC with unemployment at 6% and inflation at 2%. The natural rate is estimated at 5%. The SRPC is such that each 1 percentage point reduction in unemployment increases inflation by 0.5 percentage points. a) If the Fed wants to reduce unemployment to the natural rate (5%), what will happen to inflation? Show the new point B. b) If instead the Fed wants to reduce inflation to 1%, what will happen to unemployment? Show point C. c) Which policy is expansionary and which is contractionary? d) If the Fed does nothing, what will happen to unemployment and inflation in the long run? e) How would your answers change if the SRPC were steeper (inflation more responsive to unemployment)?

step_by_step.explanation: Unemployment falls from 6% to 5% (1 point reduction). Inflation increases by 0.5 × 1 = 0.5 points. New inflation = 2% + 0.5% = 2.5%. Point B: u=5%, $\pi$=2.5%.
Inflation falls from 2% to 1% (1 point reduction). This requires unemployment to rise by 1 / 0.5 = 2 percentage points. New unemployment = 6% + 2% = 8%. Point C: u=8%, $\pi$=1%.
Moving to B (lower u, higher $\pi$) is expansionary policy. Moving to C (higher u, lower $\pi$) is contractionary policy.
In the long run, if the economy is left alone, it will return to the natural rate (5%) at the original expected inflation (2%), assuming no shocks. But the path depends on expectations.

If the SRPC were steeper (say $\beta$=1), then a 1 point u reduction increases $\pi$ by 1 point, and a 1 point $\pi$ reduction requires only 1 point u increase. The trade-off is different—inflation is more sensitive to unemployment.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) B: 5% u, 2.5% $\pi$. b) C: 8% u, 1% $\pi$. c) B expansionary, C contractionary. d) Return to natural rate at 2% $\pi$. e) Steeper curve means larger inflation changes for given u changes.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Policy choices involve moving along the SRPC. The slope determines the trade-off.

worked_examples.title: Credibility and Disinflation

image.alt: Two Phillips Curve graphs comparing high and low credibility disinflations
image.caption: Figure 8.4.13: Compare disinflation under high and low credibility.

worked_examples.problem: Two countries, A and B, both have inflation at 8% and unemployment at the natural rate of 5%. Both want to reduce inflation to 2%. Country A has a highly credible central bank with anchored expectations. Country B has low credibility, and expectations are adaptive (based on past inflation). a) Using the Phillips Curve framework, explain why the disinflation will be less costly in Country A. b) Show graphically the path of unemployment and inflation in each country. c) What role does the speed of expectations adjustment play? d) If both countries use the same contractionary policy, what will happen differently? e) How can Country B build credibility over time?

step_by_step.explanation: In Country A, because the central bank is credible, its announcement of lower inflation may reduce inflation expectations immediately. This shifts the SRPC down, allowing inflation to fall without as large an increase in unemployment. In Country B, expectations are based on past inflation, so they adjust slowly. The SRPC remains high, so reducing inflation requires a prolonged period of high unemployment.

For Country A: SRPC shifts down quickly as expectations adjust. The economy moves along a shifting curve to lower inflation with only modest unemployment rise. For Country B: SRPC shifts slowly. The economy moves along the initial SRPC to high unemployment, then gradually the SRPC shifts down as expectations adjust, and unemployment slowly returns to natural rate.
In Country A, expectations adjust quickly (rational expectations with credibility). In Country B, they adjust slowly (adaptive expectations). Faster adjustment reduces the sacrifice ratio.
If both use the same contractionary policy, Country A will see inflation fall faster and unemployment rise less. Country B will see a deeper and longer recession before inflation falls.

Country B can build credibility by: consistently pursuing low inflation over time, adopting an inflation target, increasing central bank independence, improving transparency and communication, and demonstrating commitment through actions.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Credibility allows expectations to adjust quickly, shifting SRPC down. b) Country A: smaller u rise; Country B: larger u rise. c) Faster adjustment reduces cost. d) Same policy yields different outcomes. e) Consistent policy, independence, transparency.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Credibility improves the trade-off and reduces the cost of disinflation by shaping expectations.

process_flow.process: Identify Current Position and Natural Rate
process_flow.description: Policymakers estimate where the economy is on the SRPC relative to the natural rate of unemployment.
process_flow.mechanism: Compare actual unemployment to estimates of natural rate. Assess current inflation relative to target. Determine if economy has slack or is overheating.

image.alt: Phillips Curve graph showing current point and natural rate
image.caption: Figure 8.4.14: Step 1 - Identify current position relative to natural rate.

process_flow.description: Policymakers assess the slope of the SRPC and the state of inflation expectations.
process_flow.mechanism: The slope determines how much inflation changes for a given change in unemployment. Expected inflation determines the position of the SRPC. Credibility affects how expectations might change with policy.

image.alt: Phillips Curve graph with slope and position noted
image.caption: Figure 8.4.15: Step 2 - Assess the slope of the SRPC and the state of expectations.

process_flow.description: Based on goals (inflation target, employment mandate) and the current position, choose expansionary or contractionary policy.
process_flow.mechanism: If unemployment above natural rate and inflation below target → expansionary policy (move up SRPC). If unemployment below natural rate and inflation above target → contractionary policy (move down SRPC).

image.alt: Arrow showing policy choice along SRPC
image.caption: Figure 8.4.16: Step 3 - Choose policy direction based on goals and position.

process_flow.description: Policy is implemented, moving the economy along the SRPC. Effects are monitored.
process_flow.mechanism: Expansionary policy reduces u, raises $\pi$. Contractionary policy raises u, reduces $\pi$. The magnitude depends on the slope.

image.alt: Phillips Curve graph showing movement along SRPC to new point
image.caption: Figure 8.4.17: Step 4 - Policy moves economy along SRPC to new short-run equilibrium.

process_flow.description: Recognize that short-run gains are temporary. Expectations may adjust, shifting the SRPC.
process_flow.mechanism: If policy creates sustained deviation from natural rate, expectations will shift the SRPC, returning u to natural rate at new inflation level.

image.alt: Phillips Curve graph showing SRPC shift and return to natural rate
image.caption: Figure 8.4.18: Step 5 - In the long run, expectations adjust, returning u to natural rate.
